answers.answer: We believe we are eligible because: Many curators have attended Zuzalu events for more than one week. During Zuzalu (montenegro) we created a group for our trust network hackathon called 153 and in that group over 269 Zuzalians joined and participated in our events. With funding, we plan to create spaces for a 2-week event in Colorado, laying the groundwork for Q3 + Q4 in South East Asia.
answers.question: Please explain how your project meets the round-specific eligibility criteria.

answers.answer:
The way that we have measured success has changed overtime and will continue to change based on the culture of our community.

We would love to measure:
- Number of new applications to join our ephemeral groups per location
- Number of people that have at least 1 vouch from someone else from our community
- Number of curators present per event
- Number of humans that attend to our events
- Retention rate
- Job referrals
- Fundraising referrals
- Financial Sustainability

Other things that we would love to measure that are challenging:
- Did the participants give more than what they took for the event?
- Did we leave the place better than we found it?
- Did we make an impact in the community that we visited?
- Did we foster high quality experiences?
- Did we create strong bonds?
- Did we resolve conflicts? How many? What did we learn?
answers.question: How do you measure the impact of your project? Please provide examples and/or standard metrics.

answers.answer:
Since the beginning of our community, we have seen individuals and organizations creating new alliances, new bonds, new partnerships and overall new unions that are key for creating an ecosystem that supports each other.

Our community members have been constantly sharing time and space around Ethereum events (since Devcon Osaka 2019) and obviously Zuzalu being one of the most important gatherings within the Ethereum Community last year '23, we had to be there.

These gathering around the world have helped us create different experiences and experiments that have allowed us to learn about trust networks, care networks, support networks and more forms of human networks. We have also learned a lot about the creation, coordination and execution of community lead events.

During Zuzalu the Blockravers house was open to anyone that wanted to come, meet us IRL and obtained a bolivar for playing with web of trust primitives. Our house hosted workshops around coordinations, self issue identities and also some epic gatherings that left us all dreaming biggere.

During Zuconnect, we also hosted and curated almost every single day events and activities for those that wanted to share. We have hosted some incredible workshops, dinners, celebrations and even experiments with teams like the PSE's Jubmoji.

We will continue creating spaces where humanity, art, culture, creativity and love are at the center. For those reasons, I genuinely believe that Blockravers contribution is super valuable to Zuzalu and its members.

answers.answer:
Our structure has been very organic. We have been creating telegram groups for each Ethereum event that we have attended and all of those groups have been completely isolated. 

Since the beginning of the year, we started consolidating our different telegram groups  (collectively 1.5k members approx.) to a main telegram group where there is at least 1 vouch from someone within the community. Till today we have 618 members and +459 pending for review or vouch.

We are currently evaluating the different possibilities for hosting our community during ETHDenver and Breckenridge. The locations where we will be sharing will be completely dependant on the different partners that want to share their space with our community which is something that has been constantly happening since our inception and our ability to get some funds for hosting our own spaces.

With or without funds we will meet and continue creating these spaces that make us feel alive.

answers.answer: Criteria 1: All four members of our team (Janine, Gary, Timour, and Vjera) were organizers of past Zuzalu events, so we have each been at Zuzalu for longer than a week.   Criteria 2: We are building villages with a focus on open tech, science, health, and social innovation. We will gather people from diverse fields such as Crypto, ZK, Health & Biotech, Longevity, AI, Philosophy, Public Goods, and Governance, so we are confident that we will create events that fit within the ethos and interest areas of the Zuzalu community.
answers.question: Please explain how your project meets the round-specific eligibility criteria.

answers.answer:
We will measure impact in four key areas: 

1) **Helping to grow the movement:** We aim to continue to create high-quality popup village experiences that inspire people to host their own. We will measure this with metrics like the number of attendees (aiming for 1000+ in 2024), NPS Review Scores (Aiming for over 4.8/5), and how many people go on to start their own similar projects.

2) **Local Impact:** We have a goal to drive real world impact through our activations. For example, for the event in Southeast Asia, we will be doing outreach work and getting local communities engaging with crypto products. We will use metrics like “Number of new people with an ENS domain” to track the efficacy of this initiative. We have a related goal of encouraging IRL applications of crypto, with products like Daimo and ZuPass.

3) **Accelerating resident impact and incubating projects:** Our gatherings are perfectly designed for collaboration and growth. We want to empower attendees to do their most impactful work by helping them incubate projects within the community. We will measure this with metrics like the number of open-source projects that we see developed or meaningfully grown over people’s time in Edge City.

4) **Advancing governance and community models:** We aim to demonstrate new models of community living. Innovation villages are IRL labs for new decision-making and organizational models, allowing us to try innovative governance and community designs that align with the development of technology and infrastructure. We will measure this with metrics like the number of times attendees engage in novel governance models at each village and metrics on individual health outcomes.

Ultimately, we will measure our impact based on the real-world tangible impact that our community members and their projects will have. To do so, we will continue to foster a culture of open source and public goods innovation.
answers.question: How do you measure the impact of your project? Please provide examples and/or standard metrics.

answers.answer:
It is extremely important to us that the Zuzalu movement and community continue to flourish. We will use the funds we raise here to actively support partnerships with other popup village communities. 

We also hope that by continuing to organize high-quality events, we can help to drive the movement forward, set an example of how these villages work, and encourage others to build their own. **We are committed to openly sharing everything we learn.** 

We are also excited to continue to cultivate an ecosystem of Digital Public Goods that can be built at our events and used by all communities. Likewise, we are excited to experiment with the learnings and products that are made at our sister events and help to iterate on them.

answers.answer:
We have several specific events planned for 2024, and this funding will help us start to put down deposits to execute them. We’ll start the year with a small launch event at ETH Denver, but our primary focus will be on two long-term experiences: 

- A **one-month popup village in the Bay Area in June.** This event will help us expose top builders and funders in the SF tech scenes to our experiences. We want the ~150 hundred full-time residents (as well as the many visitors) to have an incredible experience and leave inspired to help build the movement as it grows.

- A **6-8 week popup village in the fall in South East Asia.** The goal is to bring together several hundred people for another long-term event as part of the road to DevCon 2024. We want to create an environment for global innovators to come together and explore multidisciplinary and multicultural collaboration. This event will be familiar in style and structure to many who have been to Zuzalu before but with an even greater emphasis on health and making it accessible to folks with children.

The funding from the QF round will go directly towards organizing these pop-up villages. In particular, we will need to put down deposits on large elements like venues soon.

project.title: Edge City
project.description:
**Edge City is a new organization that will convene people working at the frontier of tech, science, and society in popup villages across the globe. We aspire to be a ‘society incubator’— a lab of experimentation for new ideas, tech, culture, and organizations, all dedicated to accelerating human flourishing.**
 
Edge City is being built by Janine, Gary, Timour, and Vjera in collaboration with many Zuzalu community members. Janine and Vjera were some of the organizers of Zuzalu Montenegro and were joined by Gary and Timour to help build ZuConnect.

We are proud members of the Zuzalu ecosystem and we are excited to continue to build toward Zuzalu’s mission of cultivating a network of communities at the intersection of open technology, science, health, and social innovation. Our experience in organizing these types of events gives us confidence that we can continue to innovate and improve them. We are committed to sharing what we learn as we go. 

Our goal is to create transformative gatherings with participants from diverse fields, including Crypto, ZK, Health & Biotech, Longevity, AI, Philosophy, Public Goods, and Governance. Attendees will learn, build, focus on their health, and have fun! These playgrounds will be nexus points of new and existing innovator communities and will be co-created by the participants themselves.

Our plans for 2024 include a **one-month village in Northern California in June** and a **6-8 week gathering in Southeast Asia** leading up to DevCon 2024.

project.title: JUJALU
project.description:
Proposal for Gitcoin Grant: JUJALU - Network of BCI-ACC Houses
"JUJALU CoBrain: Bridging Bio Brains and Silicon Brains"

Objective: 
To launch the JUJALU CoGenius event, aimed at fostering innovation in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) to mitigate existential risks to humanity. This will be achieved by establishing a network of houses in key cities, each addressing a different problem and attracting local talent to collaboratively work on BCI superintelligence projects.

Description:
JUJALU CoBrain, an interdisciplinary event focusing on BCI and brain longevity, seeks to establish a network of BCI movement houses in potential locations such as New York, New Jersey, Washington DC, Philadelphia, and Boston. Each house will address specific challenges humanity faces in maintaining consciousness with continuity and merging biological brains with the power of silicon to enhance our potential as intelligent beings. A significant obstacle in merging biological and silicon brains is the lack of collaboration between the two fields, as BCI experts often lack biological knowledge, and biologists lack computer engineering expertise.

Theme Houses:
1. Self-Preservation House: Focus on brain tissue replacement.
2. BCI Mass Adoption House: Specialize in robotic surgery.
3. Silicon-Made Brain Tissue House: Develop the Implantable Chip project.
4. CoBrain House: Identify key interface requirements.

Key Features:
1. Network of BCI Houses: Each house focuses on unique challenges to accelerate the field.
2. Collaborative Co-Living: Shared spaces for biologists, software, and hardware engineers interested in BCI to live, work, and innovate together.
3. Decentralized Science Funding: Use blockchain technology for funding solutions, such as issuing IP NFTs, and create preclinical trial DAOs for crowdfunding.
4. BCI-ACC Movement Engagement: Organize events like Central Park runs and ice skating in Boston to engage broader talent pools and promote healthy lifestyles.

Goals:
- Develop a sustainable BCI talent base for ongoing collaboration over the next five years.
- Incubate research projects with market-potential IP and prototype hacks for experiments.

Funding Request:
- Funds for the initial phase of establishing and renting 1-2 houses.
- Capital for 1-2 house operations, such as equipment purchases, and a one-month food budget for group living.

Timeline:
- ETHDenver Kick-off: [Feb 26]
- Operation of BCI Houses: [March 15] - [April 15]

This proposal leverages the unique capabilities offered by countries with looser regulatory restrictions, like Honduras, to drive invasive chip implant studies on real humans. The initial co-living experiment will start by drawing talent from areas within driving range to form the initial team. The process involves an application-based system to select high-potential individuals for limited housing options. The plan includes scaling by partnering with special regulatory zones for further experiments and studies.

project.title: Vitalia
project.description:
Vitalia.city is building a decentralised city that accelerates longevity companies. The city will be composed of "districts" in 3-5 locations. Vitalia residents are entrepreneurs and scientists that are aligned in the mission to "make death optional" by fostering the developed of novel drugs & therapies at warp speed, healthy co-living and incentive design in healthcare.

The first community is in Prospera, the special jurisdiction with a pro-progress legal system that can accelerate drug development and medical tourism.
On the island of Roatan, where Prospera is based, Vitalia is running a first pop-up city with 200+ builders from Jan 6 until April 1 (3 months, extended from 2 months).

Vitalia features 4 theme weeks:

Jan 14-21: Longevity Intro Weeks https://lu.ma/longbio2024

Jan 31 - Feb 5: Crypto Cities & Startup Societies https://lu.ma/startupsocietysummit

Feb 5-12: AI & Technological Progress https://lu.ma/vitaliaai

Feb 19-26: Pathways to Life Extension https://lu.ma/vitadao_conference_vitalia

metadata.description:
Vitalia.city is building a decentralised city that accelerates longevity companies. The city will be composed of "districts" in 3-5 locations. Vitalia residents are entrepreneurs and scientists that are aligned in the mission to "make death optional" by fostering the developed of novel drugs & therapies at warp speed, healthy co-living and incentive design in healthcare.

The first community is in Prospera, the special jurisdiction with a pro-progress legal system that can accelerate drug development and medical tourism.
On the island of Roatan, where Prospera is based, Vitalia is running a first pop-up city with 200+ builders from Jan 6 until April 1 (3 months, extended from 2 months).

Vitalia features 4 theme weeks:

Jan 14-21: Longevity Intro Weeks https://lu.ma/longbio2024

Jan 31 - Feb 5: Crypto Cities & Startup Societies https://lu.ma/startupsocietysummit

Feb 5-12: AI & Technological Progress https://lu.ma/vitaliaai

Feb 19-26: Pathways to Life Extension https://lu.ma/vitadao_conference_vitalia

eligibility.description: The goal in 2024 is to scale Zuzalu and create an open vibrant ecosystem, with multiple independent spinoffs that innovate on the original idea. We can carry the torch of Zuzalu 2023, with the experience, learnings and culture from these early days, and bring it to the next level by working with and welcoming top talent from our broader world. This round’s primary objective is to fund spinoff events, referred to as "Zu-events." This initiative is expected to significantly contribute to the fulfillment of Zuzalu's mission in the year 2024. A “Zuzalu event” is a long-duration in-person gathering whose goal is to experiment with open frontier digital and social technologies.

requirements.requirement: You should have at least one core team member who was at a Zuzalu event (Zuzalu Montenegro or ZuConnect) for a minimum of a week.
You should be open about your other sources of funding and not think of it as a factor that can disqualify you.
Event must be focused on topics the Zuzalu community values (governance, coordinations / network states, zk, AI x crypto, longevity etc.)

answers.answer: magma is a 2 week residency focused on coordination amongst builders in Africa to build our economy onchain powered by Ethereum. Yoseph Ayele  has been to Zuzalu and Zuconnect, Andy Tudhope has been to Zuzalu, and Songyi Lee has been to Zuconnect.
answers.question: Please explain how your project meets the round-specific eligibility criteria.

answers.answer:
1. Stronger peer to peer support amongst African builders working onchain.
2. Intergrations and partnerships amongst Africa focused DApps.
3. Quality mentorship, support, and integration into the global Ethereum ecosystem facilitated by supporters joining.
4. Builders making better technical and non-technical decisions with deeper access to the Ethereum world.
5. Establishing a strong foundation and open source culture to grow the magma community overtime, and the IRL experience accelerating ongoing coordination amongst builders and applications.
answers.question: How do you measure the impact of your project? Please provide examples and/or standard metrics.

answers.answer:
- Bridge the global Zuzalu community with more African builders working on crucial financial and economic infrastructures the continent desperately needs. 
- Have Zuzalu members be useful hands on towards Africa centric tools, which on use cases that have clear utility and can bring the Ethereum vision to life in reaching a billion+ users.
- Take the Zuzalu concept of residencies and apply it in a more focused and curated way in Africa.

magma is free for all participants, and we are covering accommodation, food, local transport, and programming for the duration of the residency.

This includes leading a trip with Vitalik and EF across Africa, L2 learning trips with Scroll, Arbitrum, and ETHGlobal; meetups, ZK workshops, and supporting grassroots communities in key centers of gravity. project.title: magma African founder residency
project.description:
https://borderless.africa/magma

magma is a peer-to-peer coordination point for founders building Africa’s economy and finance onchain.

It's a two week residency for ~25 builders working across the African continent, where we also have ~10 global researchers, infrastructure builders, and leaders from the Ethereum ecosystem joining.

Why does magma exist?
- The African builder community is very fragmented (54 countries, and long distances between them). If we are building decentralized applications for the large African user bases, it makes more sense to build interoperable and modular tools instead of monolithic projects. So we need stronger coordination amongst ourselves. And while several builders are in shared TG groups, IRL gatherings are critical for strong coordination and trust.
- There is a huge disconnect between African ecosystems and the global Ethereum world. No major global Ethereum conference has taken place in Africa recently (yet!), so bringing builders and researchers from overseas to the continent is going to be critical.
- magma is here to build community, and create the foundations for peer to peer support.

Structure of the 2 weeks:
- peer to peer learning, coordination, workshopping individual projects, open space.
- structured workshops and office hours by global builders on ZK, account abstraction, smart contracts, security, tokenomics, governance and DAOs, product building, etc. More 1:1s than 1:many.
- space and time for builders to build, hack, do heads down work.
- community and trust building activities, open sharing circles, fireside chats on discussions that are only able to happen IRL.

We had over 100 individuals apply for magma Cohort 1, and are selecting 25 builders the residency this March. We are doing a cohort 2 in September 2024. Our goal is to run 2 cohorts year, and do active community engagement online and regionally throughout the year to facilitate learning and cross-pollination.

Location: 90 minutes out of Nairobi. Kenya has a visa free policy, which makes it accessible for all builders from across Africa and the world.

Who: For Cohort 1, ~80% will be founders of DApps and protocols, as well as projects coming onchain.  ~20% individual builders who are working on multiple projects, researchers, and really talented folks working in Ethereum. We also have global researchers from the PSE team, EF EcoDev, Ethereum L2s, founders, community builders, and individuals playing key roles in the Ethereum ecosystem coming to support. 5 out of 10 supporters will be individuals who have been to Zuzalu before.

Do Cohort 1, learn from various experiments, and hone the path to building and growing a community of African builders bringing our economy onchain.

metadata.title: magma African founder residency
metadata.description:
magma is a peer-to-peer coordination point for founders building Africa’s economy and finance onchain.

It's a two week residency for  builders working across the African continent, where we also have global researchers, infrastructure builders, and leaders from the Ethereum ecosystem joining to support hands on.

Why does magma exist?
- Crypto and decentralized tools have a strong product market fit in Africa!  Crypto adoption is growing fast in Africa due to its utility, not just speculation. African builders are driving the creation of simple financial and economic tools that have real utility for the masses, and magma is there to support them hands on, where it matters.
- The African builder community is very fragmented (54 countries, and long distances between them). If we are building decentralized applications for the large African user bases, it makes more sense to build interoperable and modular tools instead of monolithic projects. So we need stronger coordination amongst ourselves. And while several builders are in shared TG groups, IRL gatherings are critical for strong coordination and trust.
- There is a huge disconnect between African ecosystems and the global Ethereum world. No major global Ethereum conference has taken place in Africa recently (yet!), so bringing builders and researchers from overseas to the continent is going to be critical.
- magma is here to build community, and create the foundations for peer to peer support.

Who is magma for?
For Cohort 1, we are curating a group of 25 builders, ~80% will be founders of DApps and protocols, as well as projects coming onchain.  ~20% individual builders who are working on multiple projects, researchers, and really talented folks working in Ethereum. On top of that, we also have 10 global researchers from the PSE team, EF EcoDev, Ethereum L2s, founders, community builders, and individuals playing key roles in the Ethereum ecosystem coming to support. 5/10 supporters will be individuals who have been to Zuzalu before.

Cost:
magma is free for all participants joining. Accommodation, food, local transport, and programming is fully covered. Individuals just have to get themselves to the destination airport (Cohort 1 held in Nairobi, Kenya).

Structure of the 2 weeks:
- peer to peer learning, coordination, workshopping individual projects, open space.
- structured workshops and office hours with global builders on ZK, account abstraction, smart contracts, security, tokenomics, governance and DAOs, product, etc. More 1:1s and small groups than 1:many.
- space and time for builders to build, hack, do heads down work.
- community and trust building activities, open sharing circles, fireside chats on discussions that are only able to happen IRL.

Process & cadence:
- Cohort 1: 100+ builders applied for magma Cohort 1, and we are currently selecting 25 builders the residency this March. 
- Cohort 2: planned for September 2024. Our plan is to run 2 cohorts year and grow the community.
- Active community development online and regionally throughout the year to facilitate learning and cross-pollination.

Location: 
90 minutes out of Nairobi. Kenya has a visa free policy, which makes it accessible for all builders from across Africa and the world.

Learning & iteration:
We are planning to experiment and learn a lot from Cohort 1, and hone the path to building and growing a community of African builders bringing our economy onchain!

answers.answer: Francesco Vincenti, founder of Digitalia, spent two weeks volunteering at the ZuConnect event in Istanbul. Digitalia is seeking many sources of funding from other crowdfunding campaigns and web3 grants, influential private investors in network states/startup Cities, corporate partners and local brands who see direct value in sponsoring the project, public grants from the local administrations, the Italian govt, and finally raising money from the ticket sales. Also, during Digitalia, an incubator for projects will be set up as a source of economic sustainability for Digitalia’s future with a clear ROI strategy.  Digitalia tracks are focused on:  1. Revaluation and Regeneration of Italian Culture and Territory (Surrounded by a Holistic Healthy Lifestyle Approach). 2. Innovative Environments for Entrepreneurs, Businesses and Schools.  3. Public Goods in the Era of New Smart Cities & Network States. 4. Crypto and Web3 Tools for Digital Innovation, AI, and STEM R&D.
answers.question: Please explain how your project meets the round-specific eligibility criteria.

answers.answer:
![alt text](https://i.imgur.com/YQ62VSn.png)
Digitalia has a 'build-first' approach and is forming a community of talented builders aligned by different work groups and topics. We prioritize the quality of participants over the quantity and establish clear and defined outcomes upfront. 
We want to use Digitalia as an opportunity to gain insight into Italian culture by connecting an international community of digital nomads and local digital innovators with local businesses and communities by sharing different experiences together, and positively impacting each other's development, incubating and accelerating startups and projects.
We see potential outputs in services and products such as digital consulting and apps for national usage (citizens and communities) in one or many of the following categories: digital identity, payments, education, events, smart city initiatives, and AI.
Here are some KPIs we will look at for Digitalia.
1. N. of Users of Zuzalu.city Infrastructure and Software, ZK Apps, or Similar.
2. General Economic Impact and Number of Jobs Positions and Projects Created (Direct and Indirect) and their Metrics of Success.
3. N. of Apps Created, Tested, and Adopted during and after Digitalia.
4. N. of Projects Incubated.
5. Capital Reinvested and Capital of Digitalia Internal Circulating Economy
6. N. of Local and International Businesses Involved, Consulted and N. of Partnerships formed.
7. N. of Overall Attendees and Cities/Countries of origin.
8. N. of Workshops, Experiences, and Activities during Digitalia.
9. N. of Community Members (Telegram and other Groups) and its Continuity & Vitality.
10. Produce a Documentary and a Playbook to share best practices and inspire similar efforts in Italy and track the Social Media and overall Media Engagement from these and more Digitalia Contents.
11. Individual and Community Wellbeing: Tracking the overall Impact of the experience on Happiness, Intellectual Curiosity, Social Engagement with Meaningful Connections, and willingness to have a more Positive Impact on the world.
12. N. of Digitalia Spin-Off Activities Inspired in Italy.
answers.question: How do you measure the impact of your project? Please provide examples and/or standard metrics.

answers.answer:
Firstly, we acknowledge Zuzalu 2023 as the main inspiration to turn an event into a longer-term builders village. As a Zuzalu spin-off, Digitalia aims to use the village-event format to create value for a local community and the socio-economic landscape of the country of Italy by bringing digital public goods to life.
We see Digitalia as a contribution and continuation to Zuzalu by leveraging the software Zuzalu.city and Zupass. Digitalia will be listed on Zuzalu.city and the ticketing and ZK check-ins will be powered by Zupass. We see great value in having the opportunity to keep testing the tools and experimenting with new use cases that can emphasize the Zuzalu principles through his digital infrastructure, and consequently create new value for Zuzalians to benefit from them after us. 
We hope that Digitalia's learnings will add overall value and a diverse perspective on experiences gained during the 2024 archipelago of Zu-Villages worldwide, and can contaminate other Zuzalians. We want Digitalia to become a model for future similar spin-offs, aiming not only to establish Italy as an attractive business hub for Zuzalians but also to welcome more digital nomad communities.
In an era of economic uncertainty in Italy, Digitalia can act as another example to gain experience by testing Zuzalu as a new operating system for future civilization models to thrive, providing a model for encouraging solutions, decentralized leadership, and optimism for a more sustainable future.

answers.answer:
![alt text](https://i.imgur.com/HbveIF5.jpeg)
- Francesco Vincenti started developing Digitalia after attending ZuConnect in Istanbul and then inviting Zuzalu community members to speak at web3 events in Italy.
- Digitalia's core team, which has direct experience in more than 50 web3 events in Italy with a total of 7000+ participants, is not completed yet and is progressively expanding and welcoming onboard more members. We also have many advisors. The funding will help pay for the team’s time and efforts.
- The location scouting process has already started and the funding will provide a further boost to cover travel expenses and accelerate conversations to partner with local stakeholders.
- A first total budget estimation is done, with even inputs from many core Zuzalians. The team is also aware of the main challenges such as logistics, location scouting, security, bureaucracy, and budget prediction. Strategies and consultant teams are being developed to solve these issues successfully.
- A large network has been already informed about the possibility of Digitalia, and there has been favorable interest. On Jan 13th, the project was announced publicly at our preparative “Network State Meetup” in Milan to 200+ people. [link](https://twitter.com/fravincenti1/status/1747250304033177805)
- Marketing materials and campaigns are under development, with a roadmap that goes from outreach to media outlets to IRL meetups.
- The scopes and themed tracks development is underway, with a focus on meeting local wants and needs. The agenda, speakers, and daily activities are still in the brainstorming stage and will require further refinement.

answers.answer: Francesco Vincenti is the driving force behind Digitalia, with a solid background in different fields of tech, web3, and co-founding the Dao “Sewer” and “NFTcc” in 2021. With more than 50 events organized in 4 main cities, from small meetups to 300+ people conferences, Francesco and his team nurtured and shaped web3 culture in Italy, and expanding into creating more events’ formats like “AI Factory”, XR, and human-machine interaction. In January 2024, with the first Network State Meetup in Italy, Francesco expanded the relationship with Italy's top web3 communities which run the biggest local Ethereum conferences and hackathons: ETHMilan, ETHRome, NapulETH and SpaghettETH. Together we decided to promote Digitalia as the country's first web3 hub, which might even serve as a central housing location and facilitate traveling for selected attendees coming for those Ethereum events this year, all planned to happen during the same month.
answers.question: Anything else you'd like to share about your project, previous work, or other project affiliations?

answers.answer: We're currently running location scouting in Tuscany and Umbria regions, but we still need to do more vetting in Q1-Q2. We aim to bring Digitalia into a natural or rural area that is demanding more development. We’re also looking at rural/maritime zones around Rome, Emilia-Romagna, and rural areas near Milan or Venice.  Hosting The Digitalia Village in a natural area (cd."Borghi") represents the first step toward setting up a sustainable ecosystem of local synergies that can tackle depopulation and degradation in Italian real estate and areas away from the main cities.  The Digitalia Village will be located in a gorgeous setting and will provide participants with a high standard of living. Access to local healthy cuisine, Mediterranean weather, millenary hospitality culture, local artisans, and art and culture activities all will contribute to a well-rounded lifestyle. Participants can attend local activities, and actively participate in the local communities’ experiences development, and might even learn the Italian language and take cooking classes!

project.title: Digitalia: a Zu-Village in Italy
project.description:
Digitalia: A Zu-Village, is a pop-up village in Italy, launching in September 2024.
The primary goal of Digitalia is to lay the foundation stone for a permanent digital innovation hub in Italy and make it a landmark for digital and web3 talents, local and international, where they can travel to connect, collaborate, and live together. Digitalia’s mission is to unite the crypto community with the iconic Italian territory, culture, and local businesses. 
As an example of synergy between innovation and tradition, Digitalia will play a role in driving the country’s digitization while preserving the historic “Made in Italy” label. 
Digitalia is inspired by Balaji’s "The Network State" and by Zuzalu, physically connecting highly aligned online communities to address real-world challenges. We want to use emerging digital tools like cryptocurrency and AI to develop Minimum Viable Products (MVPs) as solutions for digital illiteracy in Italy.
The builder's experience is designed to last one month, immersed in the Italian beauty and traditions. Digitalia is intended for anyone passionate about contributing to Italy's digital future. While the village is open to both Italians and non-Italians, the primary goal is to develop collaboration among individuals committed to improving Italy's digital public goods and the business ecosystem in Italy. 
Digitalia is born to address a critical challenge within Italy's business environment: fostering entrepreneurship by providing easy access to a supportive ecosystem of resources for mentoring, incubating, and funding innovative projects. Digitalia will create a fund to accelerate projects and startups with Italian leaders within the pop-up village, harvest Italian talent, and digitally innovate the local high-quality and celebrated skills in design, manufacturing, engineering, art and culture, education, agriculture and food, fashion, and more.
An incubator is a baseline to create a sustainable business model and measure the economic and social impact of Digitalia, with the long-term goal of establishing a local alternative for providing public goods and influencing policy decisions in the country.

project.title: H.E.R. DAO Tech City
project.description:
H.E.R. DAO is a diverse **developer** and **builder** pipeline focused on **women** - championing innovation and diversity in the Web3 space.

**In the past**

- 10 subdaos across all continents
- 800+ scholars
- 20+ hackathons
- 10+ hacker houses

**2024**

- 4 tech cities
- 1 H.E.R. DAO Global Hackathon
- 1 Africa Tour
- 5 Main events
- 3 Hacker Houses

**The H.E.R. DAO Tech City Program**

This year H.E.R. DAO is organizing 4 tech cities, it's a **special program and a self-governing community run entirely by women** that has several vocations:

- Train **women core devs** (20+ per tech city) around **governance, ZK and public goods topics**.
- Support the local community (around 100 people per tech city) with **local meetups, workshops and mini hacks** led by our women core devs.

Each tech city will last 15 days and will welcome several women residents to support the local community.

At the end of the H.E.R. DAO Tech City program, we are organizing a **H.E.R. DAO Global Hackathon**, which will take place during **Devcon** to bring together all our international and local builders.

The roadmap for the tech cities will soon be revealed publicly! 👀

- 1 Africa Tour
- 5 Main events
- 3 Hacker Houses

**The H.E.R. DAO Tech City Program**

This year H.E.R. DAO is organizing 4 tech cities, it's a **special program and a self-governing community run entirely by women** that has several vocations:

- Train **women core devs** (20+ per tech city) around **governance, ZK and public goods topics**.
- Support the local community (around 100 people per tech city) with **local meetups, workshops and mini hacks** led by our women core devs.

Each tech city will last 15 days and will welcome several women residents to support the local community.

At the end of the H.E.R. DAO Tech City program, we are organizing a **H.E.R. DAO Global Hackathon**, which will take place during **Devcon** to bring together all our international and local builders.

The roadmap for the tech cities will soon be revealed publicly! 👀

project.title: Proof of Retreat
project.description:
Proof of Retreat is a three-month self-custodial village that aims to create an inspiring and novel experience for Zupeople & Tech Nomads, a unique space where three core values of co-living, co-working, and co-chilling meet. 

We are inspired by the idea of creating a community where each individual can put themselves in a playground with like-minded innovators, and preserve the balance of productivity and relaxation.

Proof of Retreat is your Zuspot in the south of Vietnam during high kitesurfing season annually from January till March.

answers.answer: MetaCamp is a playground for global regenerative thinkers and doers. We are advocating for the advancement of human potential by going deep with each and every attendee, breaking down the walls between our various backgrounds and creating cohesive experiences that unlock the desires and values of our event goers. Our unconference structure allows content to emerge naturally and covers topics such onchain governance, human coordination, AI, health + wellness, & interpersonal communication. The conversations and experiences attendees have at MetaCamp echo into the wider world, showing up on stages and in repo's around the world to push the adoption of these technologies forward in a meaningful and intentional way.
answers.question: Please explain how your project meets the round-specific eligibility criteria.

answers.answer:
We use follow up surveys for each event. For the most recent event, we have:

- A net promoter score of 73

- An overall attendee rating of 8.7 out of 10

- 30% of MetaCamp attendees have attended a Zuzalu event. 

The event is breaking even via paying vendors and donations of time from the facilitators and project managers that make the camp happen.

We have informally tracked several metrics and plan to do so more formally at the upcoming 4th iteration of the event, including:

- Relationships: using social network analysis to track new connections and quality of connections so that we can have data about the network we are weaving.

- Collaborations: tracking the number of new collaborations that happen as a result of connections made at metacamp.

These are just a few of the ways we measure our impact as well as the more intangible elements such as sense of closeness, community bonds, and knowledge transfer among attendees, after all this event is a living system and we’ll be constantly taking in new data points for consideration.
answers.question: How do you measure the impact of your project? Please provide examples and/or standard metrics.

answers.answer:
It is our belief that many solutions applied to the same problem space stand a greater chance of success. Our approach is based on intentional curation of attendees and thoughtfully designed agendas for the experience. MetaCamp has proven itself among the 3 cohorts of community members who have attended, many of whom are also previous Zuzalu attendees.

The way we approach community building serves the wider mission of Zuzalu in 3 ways:

1.) This event enables an alternative space for people to gather and discuss the topics important to Zuzalu community members.

2.) It plays host to a number of families embedded in the ecosystem who currently can't justify attending an event that caters exclusively to founders or technical attendees. We believe the best approach to building a new society is to include the whole family, kids, parents, even grandparents are all welcome and provided for at MetaCamp.

3.) Beginning this year, having tested and gained faith in our methodology, we plan to share our agendas, activities, and learnings in a public and open forum such as discourse so that other communities can iterate and improve upon what we are doing and grow the movement together.

We are 3 years into these events, our 4th instantiation is happening for 2 week in May of 2024, our attendees travel from all over the world to attend the event and often continue traveling together post event.  

We are 3 years into these events, running our 4th iteration in May, we have grown from 45 to 65 attendees per session and in total have 150 people in our community.

Originally one community member was the only member running ops and administration, today we have grown the team to include 3 full time contributors and 2 part time.

With space being our only limiting factor to our expansion we are exploring the development of a 10 acres lot to build a permanent campus, which would take 18+ months to develop.

While running the events we have seen massive success in terms of cohesion between community members, projects, and dissemination of knowledge. We are well on our way to reaching our eventual goal of becoming a model “Coordination” as well as a full-time node in the Network State movement. 

Finally we are entirely self-funded after a one time grant of 5 ETH from MetaCartel in 2021.

project.title: MetaCamp IV
project.description:
MetaCamp is the home of a global tribe of regenerative thinkers, tinkers, and doers.

As digitally native communities grow in scope and resources, they are increasingly looking for ways to instantiate in the physical world thus MetaCamp aims to become the Schelling point for a wide range of attendees coming together to advance their individual and shared goals, the structure of our event gives rise to a holistic experience that blends the best of onchain research into goverance, DAOs, coordination and Network States with wellness, longevity and interpersonal connection. 

By hosting facilitated discussions, group exercises and excursions we deepen the relationships of all attendees and shed new light on our own roles in this ecosystem.

answers.answer: Our project meets the round-specific eligibility criteria, as we are: (1) Zuzalu aligned: We’re looking to build a long-term model / permutation with Zuzalu ethos with additional aspects of local integration. Similar to the 2-month pop up city in Montenegro, we’ve also successfully run multiple 2-month residencies in rural Japan as pilot programs for our project. Our community was primarily communicating on a digital platform, so this was the first temporary physical space that we were able to converge in. (2) A network state: we’re a group of highly aligned members who coordinate online, with the aim of purchasing property in multiple regions of rural Japan. We support a network of home owners in acquiring, renovating, and operating properties in tight-knit regions for cohabitation and coworking. (3) Focused on frontier technologies: our project explores how digital and physical space interact with each other. While VR and AR focus on digital worldbuilding, we are using these technologies to prototype, iterate, and work together towards creating a more persistent manifestation in the physical world. In addition to these aspects, we are focused on learning how space and culture influences wellbeing and health of its constituents: how do structures ritual and collaboration to emerge?
answers.question: Please explain how your project meets the round-specific eligibility criteria.

answers.answer:
1) Local revitalization: Number of akiya rejuvenated, number of people moving into the rural areas to help revitalize them, number of volunteers and helpers, amount of art installations and collaborations, partnership and support from local governments (in form of connections / introductions, and financial stipends)
2) Increased self agency of participants: Number of new sabbaticals undertaken / supported by our project, number of alternative pathways inspired, increase in self-sufficient artists
answers.question: How do you measure the impact of your project? Please provide examples and/or standard metrics.

answers.answer:
The first iteration of Zuzalu did an incredible job in creating a pop-up city in Montenegro that attracted a large amount of visitors united with similar values and culture. While this may have contributed to the local economy during that time, and opportunities for experiencing another culture, we are interested in learning more about the long-term sustainability impacts of these pop-up cities: are participants interested in potentially moving to the city to continue contributing to the economy long term? How much interaction occurred between temporary visitors and locals? Were there many locals that took part in workshops at Zuzalu? What we’re doing at Akiya Collective focuses on these questions, as well as how to promote more memetic value.

1) Local revitalization: We are actively learning how integration from our online community can happen with existing cities and locales — this is a balancing act of learning how to thrive in the surrounding environment with those who have been there for generations, while also maintaining and contributing our own culture that we bring from various geographical contexts. Our residency had ~30% of locals to international guests — this is reflected in our Discord member list as well. It’s important to integrate local perspectives to provide input and cultural exchange that made interactions meaningful, diversified, and have the capability to build on top of each other. It’s about balancing cultural syncretism and preservation in a way that motions toward established life-ways and architectures (social, ecological, built-environmental).

2) Persistent cultural artifacts: While Zuzalu had a strong art presence across various mediums, there hasn’t been a strong movement of Zuzalu native art telling our story, symbolizing our culture, or creating memes.
    - Art is also important for shaping the physical spaces we live in and the thoughts and feelings we have while we are there, an important part of community health and wellbeing. Beauty is a public good, and spaces and artifacts will communicate value well beyond the transient visitors who come to help create it
    - Akiya Collective will be hosting residencies in Japan devoted to visualizing Zuzalian culture in various media to increase the longevity of the community and its values.

✧ Featured on various articles, graduate theses, architectural papers, and podcasts

project.title: Akiya Collective
project.description:
Akiya Collective is a society of artists, makers, and architects restoring abandoned houses in Japan into art installations, community spaces, and interactive habitats.

We are non-profit organization and a community-driven project dedicated to creating spaces that are in harmony with the local environment.

Over the last year, we:
✧ Incorporated our legal entity, a US-based non-profit organization (with a 501c3 fiscal sponsor)
✧ Hosted two residencies, with cohorts of 10 people each, in rural areas in Izu and Nagano
✧ Developed relationships with city governments and locals, learned different renovation techniques, and produced installations
✧ Researched 100+ properties, visited 25+, and explored 5 different areas of rural Japan
✧ Established our first community home in Nagano Prefecture

We have open-sourced our process and research in an online playbook for others to learn from. In our community of 1,000+ people, there are already members who have committed to purchasing property near our base. Through our project, we are actively supporting a network of home owners in acquiring, renovating, and operating properties in tight-knit regions for cohabitation and coworking.

During this grant round, we are looking to crowdfund for renovations for our first community home, which will be hosting build weeks, and 2 additional residency programs in 2024.

project.title: Zozalu
project.description:
Zozalu

[Zo](https://twitter.com/The_Zo_World)-zalu is a 2 week event designed in homage to the pioneering ‘Zuzalu’. It’s a meticulously curated festival at [BLRxZo](https://twitter.com/BLRxZo) in Bangalore, celebrating the spirit of community, innovation, and collaboration. This event brings together like-minded builders from various disciplines to co-create and share this mosaic of experiences, knowledge, and culture.
**How**
Zozalu takes place at [BLRxZo](https://twitter.com/BLRxZo), a super-equipped facility already harnessing the Zuzalu vibes. With its proven track record of hosting over 100+ [events](https://x.com/BLRxZo/status/1713175319975166161?s=20) and numerous [residencies](https://x.com/SuperteamDAO/status/1671122527945469954?s=20), BLRxZo is battle-tested and primed for events of this caliber. Situated in Bangalore, a city synonymous with innovation and cultural diversity, BLRxZo offers an ideal backdrop for an event focused on building a decentralised, community-powered future.
**Where**
The essence of Zozalu is in its power to unite diverse talents and perspectives, creating a unique communal synergy. [BLRxZo](https://twitter.com/BLRxZo), equipped with versatile spaces including [event areas](https://twitter.com/sandeepnailwal/status/1732145555315535925?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1732145555315535925%7Ctwgr%5E196b9fc41f3bc28c14e0d5138122c1199e1612a6%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https://www.notion.so/zo-world/zkBankai-Hacker-House-91617b8908274636ae99d8403dc4b58c), [co-working zones](https://twitter.com/tusharsinhaji/status/1663816683839180800?t=hfRnCmv1SXcvdzp3xnqg8g&s=35), [residential zones](https://twitter.com/tribeacademy_in/status/1736261243927929236?s=20), [podcast studio](https://youtu.be/lSEZHVNnTfE), and [breakout areas](https://x.com/salmanneedsajob/status/1733890354083176959?s=20) which provides the perfect setting for this fusion. The event leverages the [24/7/365 café](https://x.com/cryptotribe_in/status/1729038344246722775?s=20) and the innovative [Zo](https://zo.xyz/) Club App, which allows seamless operation and interaction within the space – whether it’s token gated door access or quick tools to organise workshops or sessions. It’s a testament to the power of community-led initiatives in a high-tech, service-oriented environment, tailored for community-driven events.

”Zozalu”, thus, is not just an event; it's the future of a microcosm for communal living and collaboration, deeply rooted in the principles of decentralisation and powered by the spirit of innovation and cultural exchange. 
**Check out our most recent residency: [\mani-fest/](https://zo-world.notion.site/mani-fest-0ada02cd8fd249cf8790415655c136ab)**

eligibility.description: The goal in 2024 is to scale Zuzalu and create an open vibrant ecosystem, with multiple independent spinoffs that innovate on the original idea. We can carry the torch of Zuzalu 2023, with the experience, learnings and culture from these early days, and bring it to the next level by working with and welcoming top talent from our broader world. This round’s primary objective is to fund spinoff events, referred to as "Zu-events." This initiative is expected to significantly contribute to the fulfillment of Zuzalu's mission in the year 2024. A “Zuzalu event” is a long-duration in-person gathering whose goal is to experiment with open frontier digital and social technologies.

requirements.requirement: You should have at least one core team member who was at a Zuzalu event (Zuzalu Montenegro or ZuConnect) for a minimum of a week.
You should be open about your other sources of funding and not think of it as a factor that can disqualify you.
Event must be focused on topics the Zuzalu community values (governance, coordinations / network states, zk, AI x crypto, longevity etc.)

project.title: Ayllu
project.description:
**TL;DR:** Ayllu is a one month and a half pop-up city in Venezuela with its focus on well-being, systemic change, and social impact, in partnership with diverse local stakeholders and hosted by the Ethereum Venezuela community.

# The Invitation

There was once a fabled crypto nation, a land of faux democracy and hyperinflation, where once conquistadores got lost seeking El Dorado, and where the turn of the century saw every possible aspect of the human condition slowly collapse but the ability to dream (we call this “realismo mágico”), paving the way for every use case cypherpunks could ever imagine to be tested, from governance to finance, digital identity to privacy, where folks dreamt of transparency from illegally extracted commodities to humanitarian help, where the crypto mining lungs of the Americas were once filled, and where an appetite for risk is still part of our diet.

What can we learn from the Venezuelan story? You are invited to find an answer to this question alongside us.

# **The Proposal**

We plan to host a one month and a half pop up city either in Caracas, Margarita Island, or a mix, with its focus on wellbeing, systemic change, and social impact, in partnership with local and international NGOs and grassroots organizations, private sector groups of the entrepreneurial ecosystem, and the Ethereum Venezuela community. The program’s focus will have a hands-on approach at the core with co-designed tracks by attendees matched with local leaders for guidance in maximizing local impact. We believe a deep dive into these topics will be of great value to Zuzalu’s network.

## **Some of our goals include:**

- Expose 50+ attendees to LATAM from the perspective of Venezuela and to the use cases that inspired the early adopters of crypto and blockchain technologies.
- Host work sessions twice a week to evaluate restarting the Margarita Network State Project producing a report and solid next steps after the residency.
- Explore alternative funding methods for cyber-physical public goods like parks and neighborhoods, running at least one pilot alongside local partners.
- Soft launch [Ayllu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ayllu) (think Afropolitan for LATAM) alongside [Ashoka](https://www.ashoka.org/) Diaspora Networks.
- And more to be co-designed alongside participants.

This grant’s funds will be used to set up operations, develop our brand, launch our online presence, and continue to expand on the ideas presented here in an open way, allowing the community to take part in the design and have a say from day one in the programming, and choosing the specific location and dates of the gathering.

# **Why Venezuela?**

## **An Early Network State Promise**

Venezuela once had an independent digital jurisdiction plan very similar to how network states are envisioned today. The years are 2017-18 and the setting is Isla de Margarita. It is mostly unknown that in parallel to the regulation of crypto mining and exchanges and the creation of the government-sponsored “crypto-currency”, [Petro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petro_(token)), the local powers had the plan to turn the island [Estate of Nueva Esparta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nueva_Esparta) and its core two peninsulas of Margarita, with its 1,151 km2 (444 sq mi) and almost half a million inhabitants into an independent digital jurisdiction backed by currency, governance, and identity blockchain systems. This plan came to be with the support of governance OG crypto startup, [Bitnation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitnation).

## **Crypto-Savy Population**

Greatly in part to achieving an [overall inflation rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperinflation_in_Venezuela) of 53,798,500% since 2016, Venezuela has commonly been known across the blockchain space since its early days, slowly declining in relevance but once hailed almost as the holy grail of crypto adoption. The country once held a top place across most indicators, from [trading](https://medium.com/open-money-initiative/latin-american-bitcoin-trading-follows-the-heartbeat-of-venezuela-71a28cb86ba0) to [mining](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/cryptocurrency/cheap-electricity-a-boon-for-bitcoin-mining-in-cash-strapped-venezuela/articleshow/85824225.cms?from=mdr), only to fall fast and hard after government regulation, but in parallel having crypto set front and center by this same government’s own token initiative, the ([recently defunct](https://www.barrons.com/news/venezuela-kills-off-petro-cryptocurrency-1e2b0317)) Petro. To this day, even if the average Venezuelan has a slight know-how of what crypto is, the population has moved 92.5% of total transactions to CEX’s, according to [Chainalysis](https://www.chainalysis.com/blog/2023-global-crypto-adoption-index/). And Binance and USDT are top of mind when chatting to locals. Regardless, and in the same Chainalysis report, you can find a dedicated section on “[cryptocurrency as a weapon against authoritarianism](https://www.chainalysis.com/blog/latin-america-cryptocurrency-adoption/)” in Venezuela. So, what changed and what can we learn from it?

## **Sacred Nature & Healing**

We’ve partnered with [Eposak](https://www.eposak.org/), the social impact branch of Grupo Maso, the most influential tourism operator of the country, to explore having an offsite to Canaima and visit [Mount Roraima](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aGv_MitUe7A), one of Earth’s oldest geological formations, composed of Proterozoic age sandstone formed about 1.7 to 2 billion years ago and the inspiration for the Disney/Pixar movie Up. Alongside Eposak and Ashoka,  our team leader is currently exploring the use of web3, mixed-reality, and other technologies in generating alternative sources of income for local communities in the area.

# **Team, Contacts & Other Round Eligibility Questions**

The team is made of four of the 28 Ethereum Venezuela volunteers and is led by one of its co-founders, Daniel K. ([@kosmostasis](https://t.me/kosmostasis)) who has been in the space since 2010. He’s been a former contributor to Bitnation, Democracy Earth Foundation, RadicalxChange, Commons Stack, Token Engineering Commons, and IoTeX, among others. He’s a co-instigator of the B Corps and Singularity University communities in Venezuela, as well as the civic innovation space LABO Ciudadano, former Alumni Network Vice-Chair of the Young Leaders of the Americas Initiative and a Kernel Block II fellow, he’s also supported many different initiatives both locally and regionally that allow him to keep a multi-stakeholder approach to systemic change. K attended both Zuzalu ‘23 as a Visitor and ZuConnect as a Resident. Here’s his [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/knobelsdorf/) for a more complete profile. We aim to recruit other leaders of the web3 space of Venezuelan origin as advisors or core team members.

You can find us at https://t.me/ayllufam and [ayllufam@gmail.com](mailto:ayllufam@gmail.com). The initiative has no prior funding, or on-chain attestations/impact certificates.
